item.title: How I‚Äôll choose what product to build
item.description:
I‚Äôll divide the process into two main stages.

Creating a list of ideas and initial selection

Following the recommendation from Peter Levels‚Äô book Make, I‚Äôll focus on problems I‚Äôve personally encountered.

In the first step, I‚Äôll create a rough list of problems and potential product ideas that come to mind. Then I‚Äôll narrow it down to a maximum of three ideas for deeper analysis. The goal is to find something that solves a real problem and has a chance of actually being useful to others.

Next, I‚Äôll describe these products on my blog and ask for feedback in places where I can find potential users.

Describing the Three Selected Product Ideas

Each product description will include:

  1. Name and Description ‚Äì A short summary of the product and the problem it solves. I‚Äôll explain why the problem is important and how solving it could help people.
  2. Target Audience ‚Äì Who will benefit the most from this product.
  3. Competition and Differentiation ‚Äì What similar solutions already exist and how my product will be different or better.
  4. Business Model ‚Äì How I plan to make money from this product and what costs I expect.
  5. Marketing Ideas ‚Äì How I could get people interested in the product.
  6. Concerns and Challenges ‚Äì What I‚Äôm worried about and what might be hard during the process.

Main Goal for May 2025

My goal for this month is to clearly describe these ideas using the structure above and define what I can quickly build to test market interest ‚Äî a scope of work for an MVP. It‚Äôs important to check as early as possible if the market really needs the solution, before I invest more time and resources into it.

item.title: Why am I going to build a product?
item.description:
The list will be sharp and to the point, without any filler.

  • I‚Äôll have full decision-making power over what I do and how I do it.
  • I enjoy pursuing goals I set for myself. After completing a demanding AI course and an algotrading bot project, I‚Äôm looking for a new, bigger challenge.
  • My favorite part of professional work is designing and building systems.
  • This is one of two paths I‚Äôve been considering for years. It seems less risky than the other one‚Äîbuilding my own service-based company.
  • I‚Äôve always had a few product ideas in mind.
  • I want to do something beyond working for someone else. The main stage of building my professional career is already behind me.
  • Nothing truly bad will happen if I fail ‚Äî at worst, I‚Äôll gain valuable experience and learn something.
  • I‚Äôm inspired by people who have done it, like Troy Hunt and his Have I Been Pwned project
  • I was inspired by Peter Levels‚Äô book Make, in which he shares his experiences building startups solo.
  • In the future, I‚Äôd like to be able to say: ‚ÄúI once built my own product, even though I wasn‚Äôt sure it would work out.‚Äù
  • I‚Äôd like to build a personal brand along the lines of ‚Äúhe makes cool stuff.‚Äù
  • Maybe I‚Äôll even make some money from it.

As I mentioned, this blog entry will also serve as a place I can return to whenever I need a reminder of why I started, especially in moments when motivation runs low.
